awd_titl_txt: Homotopy Theory of Algebras and Its Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research at the interface between mathematics and physics. The proposed projects lie at the intersection of several areas including algebra and geometry. The origin of these problems is from mirror symmetry, a recent and fascinating phenomenon discovered by theoretical physicists. As such, solutions of the proposed projects will enhance our understanding of the interaction between interesting, deep mathematics and applicable, exciting ideas from physics. Part of the funding will also be used to support graduate students to work on the proposed projects, and to travel to conferences.

The proposed projects use the homotopy theory of algebras to study categorical mirror symmetry, moduli spaces, and derived geometry. The investigator plans to work on: (1) a Whitehead type theorem for L-infinity spaces which simultaneously generalizes the classical inverse function theorem and the Whitehead theorem of L-infinity algebras; (2) proving some essential properties of the PI's previous work on the mirror construction, such as its Calabi-Yau property, vanishing of monodromy, and compactifications; (3) a general approach to define genus zero Gromov-Witten invariants of compact smooth Calabi-Yau A-infinity categories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PIs have conducted research at the interface between mathematics and 
physics, and worked on multi-disciplined problems involving algebra, geometry 
and combinatorics. The outcomes have deepened the understandings of 
mathematical aspects of mirror symmetry in high energy physics (notably, 
string theory). During the funding period, the PIs have supported a graduate 
student and mentored two undergraduate students for Summer Research 
Internships. In addition, the grant has enabled the PIs to work with their 
collaborators for joint projects and to attend academic conferences for 
professional training. 

The PIs studied the categorical Gromov-Witten invariants, and computed 
the g = 1, n = 1 B-model Gromov-Witten invariant of an elliptic curve directly 
from the derived category. Moreover, the PIs introduced a categorical analogue 
of Saito's notion of primitive forms, and proved that there exists a unique, 
up to non-zero constant, categorical primitive form for the category of matrix 
factorizations of certain singularities. Using Kontsevich's deformation 
quantization technique, the PIs presented an explicit cyclic minimal model for 
the category of matrix factorizations of an isolated hypersurface singularity. 
By showing that certain 3-point genus-0 Gromov-Witten invariant of the Hilbert 
scheme of two points on the complex projective plane is positive and can be
calculated enumeratively, the PIs verified that the Hilbert schemes of 2-points 
on rational surfaces are symplectically (= numerically) rationally connected. 
Furthermore, in the context of Okounkov's conjecture, the PIs investigated 
connections between Hilbert schemes of points on a smooth projective complex 
surface and quasi-modular forms.

Last Modified: 09/01/2021
Modified by: Zhenbo Qin
